E69825049EB84DEA967331FCAEB36A85.description: Participate in a variety of dances from New France

7A7A3F8A8946493DABB3863CFA48C20A.description: Use dance vocabulary when responding to and discussing dance performances.

E66884A086DF4B2181855F81C88DFE47.description: Participate in a variety of folk and social dances

ED58F5215FF143EA9E4327280BCA3506.description: Describe how dance can be valued in one's life and culture.

94D390C3136D40178A8FD25A213A2A4A.description: Dance in New France reflected a combination of culture and traditions

F6B5E37C14284C27978FA7AA019ABB7C.description: Dance was used as a means of entertainment, cultural adornment, or as a status symbol in ancient Rome

E941C58AA26D4854884368D7503E483A.description: Ancient Roman culture was reflected through dance traditions and beliefs

1E00CE5F00954B038D33AFF5CF0A8BA4.description: An artistic community is a venue for artistic expression within various cultures

8459EE6CA70A45879AD8DB5A52D2E840.description: Dance can be valued differently across cultures throughout history.

F8CBD788D7F24FDDA53A1ACE1442E962.description: People in New France valued dance for the significance, meaning, and function that it had in their lives, and it could be performed by anyone

EE04E69BD2624F7386A97324D390F8DF.description: European settlers introduced many folk dances, styles, and traditions to New France, including jigging the Pavane la ronde the menuet le quadrille la danse de la Galette square dance (les contredanses en carré)

0C8A9C755BBD4F939A3FBC017BAA9ECA.description: First Nations dances in New France reflected the traditions, ceremony, and rituals of the people who lived on the land for hundreds of years prior to European settlement

E507056665B14F19A4F23BB818FBE16F.description: Dance formations and pathways in ancient Rome can include choral line circular processional

F0DDE835494740A98E00311BEB346843.description: Pantomime is non-verbal style of communicating dramatic stories using gestures, music, costumes, and masks

FF9B5B43D71C4EECA020622DEFEA1A85.description: Pantomime was considered a popular form of dance in ancient Rome

806DB7296EBB479887764DA8B7AB27E5.description: Some dances in ancient Rome had protocols that specified who could dance, when dances were performed, and who the dances were performed for

8F425A56C8BD481BB87BAA06E20DE759.description: Dance in ancient Rome reflected Greek culture, including celebrating Mars, the god of war, where dancers would carry a shield and wear a full set of armor while they danced

0C8C69AADD6640E99A905B8796FDC958.description: Wealthy people in ancient Rome did not dance, but instead hired lower-class people to dance for them

039BE925E56645619F56A6B20365B0D7.description: Artistic protocols and etiquette may change based on the community, culture, presentation, and location of a dance performance.

0BC9116A8A6547BEBF24A97361EF16D2.description: Using vocabulary related to dance can contribute to and guide discussions about dance.

6FDE3114FFF2406B8F48F7D2DF2F1FD8.description: Folk dance and social dance can function as a means of participation, entertainment, and cultural expression

3B57DBD9229F4BEB80B952874678E191.description: Folk dance is a dance form that reflects the lives, traditions, or customs of a group of people from a specific country, region, or culture

71E74D9434324F0EA45AE96B72DAC39C.description: From historical times to today, cultures may have valued dance for ritual or cultural expression, entertainment, and learning

F240967444F44EC290F4BA93D479C2F1.description: Students compare and contrast dance cultures of the past with modern-day dance

CC7F830AEFAA4921AC8F9FCCCB792193.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

775D1B9B954B462F83940FBF3CF7EBF5.description: Rehearse movements and dance before performing for an audience

89481F5C865143C2A4E9F20148038A3E.description: Practise giving and receiving feedback with others

68E9CBC1569E460DBD624F95A4C83545.description: Explore movements within a variety of choreographic forms

E78F6018F7AB42AC89EFBFD0F71B6B1F.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of artistic choices in communicating a message through movement.

5D2FF7934DCF49FBA5203E7F2B048086.description: Make informed artistic choices to share a message through dance.

BBCFB1CA277743E895E625E491F02092.description: An audience can receive and interpret a message communicated through dance.

749CB6C6B585481CBC946DCA4518F51F.description: Messages can represent what a dancer means to communicate through movement

CE42EEE5257E47AC922E2E09F156C6D6.description: A message is at the centre of communication in dance

6DE5E6D3123B4A7A9147807044730EE7.description: The elements of dance can be combined in an infinite number of ways to create a message through movement.

F64369AEC42C4A92A11905FE76E3091F.description: Dancers intentionally choose ways to effectively share a message

19A6CA29106A46348AFA5E0CD3189AD8.description: Creative processes can help develop and clarify a message in dance, including reflection giving and receiving feedback refinement rehearsal

84F2272C6773452BBDCEF2EBEE21296E.description: The Round Dance is social dance often held by First Nations communities, where participants move in a clockwise direction in a circle to the beat of a drum while holding hands.

4D18AE5B30504A0A8F643241028F4EEB.description: In powwow dances, the spiritual centre of the powwow is the circle where unity and equality of participants is valued everyone can see each other in the circle there is no leader and everyone follows

CFC4888A0EFA49629EBDF76A35621C7B.description: The circle is a symbol that can communicate messages in dance, including unity

00446DFC374B4878990711F06D8A6FF3.description: The clarity of a message communicated through movement and dance can be enhanced by moving to a steady beat planning movement patterns practising movement skills combining movements with a purpose

18CFC9487F574CAEAB59AB41D4A373E6.description: A message in dance can be created in response to a variety of stimuli

7F401EBAC45A4E889991B53FD3C5D806.description: Messages can represent a variety of things, including ideas, experiences, or feelings.

6B79D4D67B594312A22BDE4A13D89433.description: Choreographic forms can structure how a message is conveyed in dance, including AB (binary form) ABA (ternary form)

25E774160B064D94AC2FE76F05953938.description: Movement ideas are shared effectively when they have a clear beginning and end.

D02320F2101C4AEB80504DA7718E54BB.description: Intentional artistic choices are made by dancers to express a message using locomotor and non-locomotor movements space, including use of proximity, levels, size, direction, and pathways body, including body parts? body shapes? balance? and relationships to other dancers, including prepositions body shapes and balance force speed

B0894D9EB1904920A217F0611BDAAD97.description: Students represent message through artistic choices related to the elements of dance.

C33EF8721277436192E1D84C9AF09AEE.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge

0336AEF354CE4F029A9218F601899A33.description: Experience how a force can emphasize a movement

FBE7B4E2FBEE414883A128DA262A5702.description: Observe a variety of dances to investigate how movement qualities can change when force is applied

6FC39930D6584197B5CB4C17575635F4.description: Investigate how meaning can be communicated when force is applied to locomotor and nonlocomotor movements.

194A7B380AF64F3BBDC9A16372E6B098.description: Perform movements that reflect the qualities of energy in various pieces of music

8B11EF5B47644ED58DEA58537FAFE757.description: Participate in warm-ups that prepare the body's muscles for executing force.

044193608960490E8C9285033ADD5C80.description: Identify how the quality of a movement can vary when strong or light weight is applied.

5543BE280E354E449EDD87E7B033517E.description: Discuss the importance of awareness for others when applying force, speed, and change of direction during movement along various pathways and in various formations.

8DB6623A4B6147749A9679EB977E7D62.description: Differentiate between smooth and sharp energy.

9C177D5E90D44DE5B47F277D521BBDA8.description: Combine element of time with other elements of dance in movement exploration

66062DF8BBC449598CDE4F122C395476.description: Respond to various stimuli in the exploration of time in dance.

3459D7EDDE014ADF88A270CCFB5A9477.description: Participate in dances that are performed to music or the spoken word

1D4C933E716F4180BF3E8D45B8D7B6FD.description: Experience counting beats silently or aloud to direct movement.

FCA611BEBFAD415BA70A80072199D37D.description: Demonstrate how to move to a steady beat at various speeds.

E66D3B3ADB9B4E9FBA71D4456DB94CDF.description: Alter movement by varying speed and responding to different rhythms

27C6A1A66597415B90E36DC6B3D20524.description: Force can communicate meaning through movement.

F7E53015BC6F43F2932AF5B65D09E609.description: Force is the amount of energy the body uses and releases in dance

8E16A7B9B7B54162803DC8231DE3414E.description: Time can be explored in relation to other elements of dance

07FF1C93EA2E493AB83FC1F5BE7B9D4D.description: Time is an element of dance that refers to the speed and rhythm of movement

B6FE69DCA64849CD9433F56ED4A2B48A.description: When applied to movement, force can intensify or emphasize parts of a movement, pattern, or phrase

61E97A9400F64D618DDEAF8C4083EF22.description: Force can communicate feelings and ideas when applied to locomotor and non-locomotor movements

E889C338424D4054AE7C80846621B967.description: Music qualities can direct how a movement is performed, including accents patterns speed dynamics

4C49A1DC41E242A58DC649312C97573F.description: Applying force to locomotor and non-locomotor movements requires a warm-up to prepare muscles body control awareness for safe movement practices

8D73814DFC7D4ED091235D933A4DA8FC.description: Movements executed with light weight require little muscular force

C9DD57A658C245ECAB0A199869D3900B.description: Movements executed with strong weight require more muscular force.

194D85B258724478A2FFF36A1FF2EF75.description: Force has energy that can be described using qualities, including smooth or sustained energy that is continuous sharp energy that produces force through sudden movements and ends quickly, including slash, punch, jump, or kick

13D28349D4904C02A9DE40DC9BD53886.description: Force is an element of dance that includes energy and weight

29FCF6E0C7BD42BF896C63D3AE5393E6.description: Concepts of time can be combined with other elements of dance, including space: place, size, levels, directions, pathways, and focus body: body parts? relationships? shapes, including symmetry and asymmetry? and balance force: energy, weight, and flow

E76C68317783494BA5AD48E3DC650268.description: Counting aloud or internalizing the number of beats in a movement pattern or dance can help a dancer know when to start and stop a movement

22972DDCB5C34C249E6514F44C2F63A1.description: Time can be explored in relation to various stimuli, including music, instruments, or the spoken word

59EB0F2DF4F846C1846C1BEF69900ACB.description: Movement patterns can include quick or slow steps performed in a sequence, which are often repetitive

2955A8832D314FF5B76689B90A010CEF.description: Rhythm includes the pulse or constant, even beat also known as the underlying beat

D4119D6096D646709AE7CD170BBBF1ED.description: Speed refers to how fast or slow the body moves through space

1FF9F116DC0E4E7F8E6567F790183E2C.description: Time is measured by how many beats a movement or stillness lasts in dance

19B71842B5D2470FA23C5AC6A9F6C8ED.description: Students evaluate time and force as it relates to quality of movement.

1E7D782D0DF543A1AC889925AD0445EC.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
